_header: As one sweet look of your eyen twain
Note:
A translation of his French poem (Champollion-Figeac (1842)
XChampollion-Figeac, Aime. Les Poesies du duc Charles d’Orleans. Paris, 1842, 30)
_description: A roundel by Charles d’Orléans — 21 lines, mostly in 5-line stanzas, with refrain, ‘As oon swete / Which wickid / As wisshe hit’

BodHerD38.First Lines:
As oon swete look of your eyen taynWhiche wickid speche doth fro me
                    refrayn…
BodHerD38.Last Lines:
…When y departed last ye did me sooWerthe fully your look for
                    to refrayn
BodHerD38.Editions:
Hausknecht,  Emil. 
             “Vier gedichte von Charles d’Orleans.” 
             Anglia
         17 (1895): 445-7: 447.
Bliss,  Philip. 
             Reliquiae Hearnianae.
         London: J. Russel Smith, 1869: 1.267.

BLHar682.First Lines:
AS oon swete look of yowre eyen tayneWhich wikkid speche doth fro
                    me refrayne…
BLHar682.Last Lines:
…As y haue thoughtis on yow where y gooOf yowre fayre body and
                    streight sidis playne
BLHar682.Note: As written, repeats first words of lines 1-3 at end to indicate going back to first lines of the roundel.
